Distill to Quarto

Last year, I wrote two extensive blog posts on designing and implementing a custom syntax highlighting theme for my website, written in {distill}. Now that I’ve rewritten my website using Quarto, this post is an update on that process for this format.

An extra colour

Quarto, like distill, uses a theme called arrow as its default. There are, however, some differences between the implementations for distill and Quarto. Firstly, when I applied my custom highlighting scheme, with its five-colour palette, to my Quarto site, I noticed an extra colour had slipped in.

Light and dark modes

## Distill to Quarto

Last year, I wrote two extensive blog posts on designing and implementing a custom syntax highlighting theme for my website, written in {distill}. Now that I've rewritten my website using Quarto, this post is an update on that process for this format.

### An extra colour

Quarto, like distill, uses a theme called arrow as its default. There are, however, some differences between the implementations for distill and Quarto. Firstly, when I applied my custom highlighting scheme, with its five-colour palette, to my Quarto site, I noticed an extra colour had slipped in.



### Light and dark modes
